titlestmt.titleproper:
Guide to The Knox Burger Archive
ca. 1969-2000
MSS 078
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Philip Lauer, Marvin Taylor in June of 2000.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from burger finding aid.doc

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2011-11-14T15:36-0500

did.abstract: Knox Burger was an editor, writer and journalist based in New York City. While serving in World War II, Burger contributed to Yank, and then after the war to such publications as Collier's. He then moved on to editing for Dell and Fawcett Publications. In 1970, he founded Knox Burger and Associates, a literary agency which later merged with the Harold Ober agency. The collection consists of Burger's correspondence from the late 1960's through 2000.

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: The Knox Burger Archive was donated to the Fales Library by Knox Burger in 2000.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Open to researchers. Appointments are necessary for the use of manuscript and archival materials.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Collection use is subject to all copyright laws. Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the Director of Fales Library and Special Collections. Please contact fales.library@nyu.edu. or call 212 998 2596.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation

bioghist.head: Biographical Note:
bioghist.p: In college, Burger was the editor of the Cornell Widow from the fall of 1942 to spring 1943. He left college in April 1943 to join the army. In the service, he contributed freelance reportage, fiction and humor to Yank, the Army Weekly. While serving with a B-29 bomb squadron in the Marianas, he covered a number of missions over Japan, and was transferred to the Yank Saipan bureau late in the summer of 1945, just before the Japanese surrender. Burger moved north to Tokyo, where he was, for a few months, the editor of the Far East edition of Yank, and wrote numerous stories about the occupation.

After the war, Burger did a brief stint at the Harvard graduate school, selling occasional fiction and articles to national magazines. In 1947, he was hired by Collier's (one of our leading defunct magazines), and became its fiction editor in 1948. In 1951, he left Collier's to edit books - mostly suspense novels - for Dell. Burger edited at Dell for 9 years, and spent 1960-1970 editing for Fawcett Publications. Among the writers he worked with during those 20 years were Kurt Vonnegut, John D. MacDonald, John Steinbeck, Ray Bradbury, Jack Finney, Horace McCoy, Walter Tevis, MacKinlay Kantor, Morris West and Louis L'Amour.

In 1970 Burger established, in partnership with his wife, Kitty Sprague, a literary agency (Knox Burger Associates), setting up in the basement of the brownstone on Washington Square in which they lived. In the spring of 2000, he merged his agency with the Harold Ober agency.
Knox Burger died in Manhattan on January 4, 2010.

p.emph: Source - from a text written for Fales by Knox Burger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Knox Burger Archive is comprised of the correspondence and manuscripts of many notable literary figures, as well as reviews of their literary works. Burger's original organization of his papers was preserved as much as possible.

The collection includes 6 boxes in one series of original and carbon copy typewritten manuscripts of Burger's correspondence with writers he represented, contracts, and reviews of their work from various periodicals. Items in the archive are arranged alphabetically by personal name.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Folders are arranged alphabetically by subject/author.
The files are grouped into one series.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: There is no information about materials that are associated by provenance to the described materials that have been physically separated or removed.
